name: 1h-imidazole, 2-phenyl-
Reason: The basic structure of imidazole has a melting point of around 90°C. Adding a phenyl group typically increases the melting point due to increased molecular weight and pi-pi interactions between aromatic rings. The phenyl group is expected to increase the melting point by around 60°C.
Test (Predicted reason):
The basic unit for comparison is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The imidazole ring introduces nitrogen atoms, which can form hydrogen bonds, increasing the melting point significantly. The presence of a phenyl group also increases the melting point due to π-π interactions and increased molecular rigidity. The imidazole ring itself can be considered as a modified benzene ring with nitrogen atoms, which would increase the melting point by approximately +100°C compared to benzene. The phenyl group adds another +40°C due to its aromatic nature and increased molecular weight.
